awd_titl_txt: Infant Growth, Milk Composition, and Maternal Energetics in a High Altitude Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
For the vast majority of human history, breast milk has been the primary source of nutrients during infancy. Recent research has shown human milk to be a tremendously complex fluid containing a wealth of macronutrients, immune factors and hormonal components, all of which get fed to the baby. Similarly, mothers' milk is incredibly variable, with women in different societies and living situations producing different amounts of many of these components. Despite a growing body of research, there is still much left to understand about how and why milk varies in different ecological circumstances and how these differences may affect the health and growth of infants. This study takes a detailed look at a population which lives in the high altitude environment of the Nubri Valley, Nepal, to investigate how breast milk may be involved in the regulation of infant growth under considerable ecological stress. The project will provide opportunities for undergraduate and graduate student research and training, and facilitate regional health and science education at the study location. Understanding how ecological pressures such as altitude and cold stress influence human milk composition and in turn, infant metabolism and physiological development, may be crucial in understanding the risk factors for overweight and metabolic dysfunction in industrialized and rapidly industrializing populations.

It is likely that there has been considerable natural selection on human milk composition given the primary role human milk has during infancy, itself a critical period of selection. Growth factors and metabolic hormones found in milk show significant associations with linear growth, weight gain, fat free mass, and size for age, making milk born hormones and cytokines likely candidates for developmental programming of infant body composition. However, these associations have never been investigated in an ecologically stressed population where environmental selection on infant phenotypes may be severe. This project will investigate associations between ecology, maternal physiology, milk composition, and infant growth and development in 115 mother-infant pairs from nine villages in the Nubri Valley of the Himalayas (Nepal). The population is ethnically Tibetan, with family histories recording occupation in the valley for at least 700 hundreds following immigration from the Tibetan plateau. Villages range in altitude from 7,500-13,100 feet above sea level. Milk samples, metabolic tests, and thermal body scans will be collected at four time points over the first year of infant life. The thermal imaging of mother and child is an innovation which will show differences in body fat patterning. Additionally, interviews of the mothers and anthropometric measurements (height, weight, body composition) of both mother and child will be collected beginning at birth and at two month intervals afterward.  The resulting data will provide the most complete picture ever collected of altitude- and seasonality-associated differences in growth, milk hormones, and maternal reproductive condition across the first year of life.

por.por_cntn:
Project overview. It is likely the environmental stressors encountered at high altitude exerted considerable selective pressure on human populations migrating into these areas.  Although high altitude exerts physiological pressures on all age groups, natural selection decreases as a function of age, making infancy one of the more important periods for selection.  Limited studies of infant health, nutrition, and growth are available for high altitude populations. Understanding how high altitude influences milk composition, especially the hormones involved in growth and metabolic development, may shed light on how developmental plasticity may have contributed to human adaptation particularly under considerable environmental challenges such as those experienced at high altitude.

Project design. Over a 3 year period, all ethnically Tibetan individuals who gave birth in the rural valley of Nubri, Nepal were invited to participate in a 18 month study of infant growth, milk composition, and maternal health. Community health workers, living in Nubri, collected monthly data on 83 participants for the first 18 months of life (length, weight, skinfolds, health and dietary recalls) on mothers and infants. Seasonally, milk samples, maternal metabolic rates, and infant thermal stress were accessed using standard methodologies to better understand how high altitude stressors such as hypoxia are mitigated by maternal and infant biology in a high altitude adapted population.

 

Project Broader Impacts.

Community: Health related workshops were hosted as part of the CBPR framework of this project. Communities nominated topics and the team designed and hosted workshops on the topics every six months. All workshops were lead by either individuals from Nurbi who were trained as nurses) or by Nepali nurses with research staff serving as translators.

Capacity Building in Nepal: Six Nepalis were employed by the project from 2015-2019 with additional staff rotated in as necessary. Clinics were supplied and trained in measuring infant and children’s growth and development and treating malnutrition.

Student training in the USA: More than 20 graduate and undergraduate students, over half students from historically excluded backgrounds, have worked on the data and laboratory portions of this project. Two students worked directly with communities while the PI (Quinn) was on family leave. Students have been part of several publications, had opportunities to present their research findings at local and national conferences.

Project Intellectual Merit. This was the first study to investigate infant and young child growth in a high altitude adapted community using a longitudinal framework. It has the potential to dramatically change how we understand the impact of high altitude stressors, such as hypoxia and undernutrition, on infant and child growth and development. In many instances, it showed that hypoxia was not a primary driver of child size in this sample. Increased understanding of how high altitude adapted infants and young children growth at high altitude may improve our understanding of how to promote the growth of premature infants who face many of the same physiological challenges.
